Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Can Evolutionary History Predict How Changes in Biodiversity Impact the Productivity of Ecosystems?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists seek to understand how the current accelerating loss of biodiversity will affect the productivity and sustainability of Earth's ecosystems. The goal of this project is to predict which species extinctions will have the greatest effect on primary production, the fundamentally important process of photosynthetic capture of biomass. This project tests the novel hypothesis that evolution leads to genetic divergence and niche differences among species. In turn, niche differences lead to a 'division of labor' that determines how efficiently biological communities capture the limited resources needed to produce new biomass. To test this hypothesis, the project bridges the fields of ecology, phylogenetics, and genomics to examine how one of the most widespread and ecologically important groups of algae impacts the productivity of lakes throughout North America. The goals are to 1) Create a new molecular phylogeny that can be used to test whether assemblages of freshwater algae are more genetically diverse than expected by chance. 2) Experimentally manipulate the evolutionary and genetic divergence of species to assess how these aspects of biodiversity control niche differences and primary production. 3) Conduct analyses of gene expression data to identify the genetic basis of niche differences among species, and relate these to rates of primary production by phytoplankton communities.

The project will train a variety of students from high school interns to postdoctoral researchers in multidisciplinary work blending genomics, phylogenetics, and ecology. Two K-12 exercises will broaden students' appreciation for biological diversity in important freshwater habitats. The information from the project will provide important information for the management of freshwater resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to understand the impact of species loss and species invasions on ecological functions, we must understand the relationships between genes, species, evolution, and ecological functions. In a long series of related publications, we studied North American green algae as a model system. Using high throughput sequencing, we generated a data rich evolutionary history of common green algae that can be grown in labs. With knowledge of their evolutionary history, we explored how relatedness of species compares to gene expression differences and to competition between species, when algae are grown alone or in various experimental communities. Contrary to the commonly asserted "competition-relatedness hypothesis" (CRH), we do not find that competition is greatest among close relatives in our experimental communities. In natural systems, we found that almost all green algae in North American lakes are distributed randomly with respect to relatedness, again counter to predictions of the CRH. We did find that gene expression differences (across whole transcriptomes) are more similar in close relatives. Surprsinigly, we also found that species that competed less had more similar overall gene expression. In order to analyze the large transcriptomic and phylogenetic data sets we produced, we created many bioinformatics tools to allow researchers to conduct phylogenetic analyses in the Galaxy bioinformatics platform.

In summary, we created a model system to investigate interactions between genes, species and their evolutionary histories, and ecological functions. We used this model system to discover that the widely held compeition-relatedness hypothesis may not be general. Our research accomplished sigificant progress toward understanding the relationships between gene expression, species relatedness, and ecological interactions. This information becomes increasingly critical as species become extinct, and as the ranges of species change through human activities.
